title: The Jews' Victory and Purim Established
shortSummary: Esther 9 recounts the Jews' deliverance from their enemies on the appointed day, turning a day of expected destruction into one of triumph and celebration. It details the defeat of Haman's sons, the establishment of the feast of Purim, and the enduring ordinance for the Jewish people to remember their salvation annually.
timeline: c. 5th century BC - Persian Empire under King Ahasuerus

keyCharacters.name: Esther
keyCharacters.description: The Jewish queen who intercedes for her people and secures the king’s permission for the Jews to defend themselves.

keyCharacters.name: Mordecai
keyCharacters.description: Esther’s cousin and guardian, a prominent Jew in the king’s court who leads the Jewish people and establishes the feast of Purim.

keyCharacters.name: King Ahasuerus
keyCharacters.description: The Persian king who authorizes the Jews to defend themselves and later confirms the institution of Purim.

keyCharacters.name: Haman’s Sons
keyCharacters.description: The ten sons of Haman, the enemy of the Jews, who are executed as part of the Jewish victory.

definitions.definition: The twelfth month of the Hebrew calendar, during which the events of Esther 9 take place.
The lot cast by Haman to determine the day for the destruction of the Jews, giving the name to the feast of Purim.
A wooden structure used for execution by hanging, notably where Haman’s sons were hanged.
Celebratory practices established by the Jews to commemorate their deliverance and God’s providence.

outline.heading: The Jews Defend Themselves and Defeat Their Enemies
outline.description: On the 13th of Adar, the Jews successfully defend themselves throughout the Persian Empire, including the capital Shushan, killing their enemies without taking spoil. This reversal of fortune highlights God’s providential protection.

outline.heading: Extension of the Jews’ Victory in Shushan
outline.description: Esther requests and receives permission for the Jews in Shushan to continue their defense for an additional day, resulting in further victories and the execution of Haman’s ten sons.

outline.heading: The Jews’ Rest and Celebration
outline.description: The Jews rest on the 14th and 15th of Adar and establish these days as times of feasting, gladness, and mutual giving, marking their deliverance as a joyous occasion.

outline.heading: Mordecai’s Letter Instituting Purim
outline.description: Mordecai formalizes the observance of Purim through letters to all Jewish communities, commanding annual remembrance of their salvation through fasting, feasting, and charity, ensuring the legacy of God’s deliverance endures.

application: Trust in God’s providence even when circumstances seem dire, knowing He can turn situations in your favor.
Stand firm in faith and courage to defend righteousness and the wellbeing of God’s people.
Celebrate and remember God’s deliverance regularly through worship, thanksgiving, and acts of kindness.
Obey God’s ordinances and pass down the faith and its teachings faithfully to future generations.

keyVerses.text: Now in the twelfth month, that is, the month Adar, on the thirteenth day of the same, when the king's commandment and his decree drew near to be put in execution, in the day that the enemies of the Jews hoped to have power over them, (though it was turned to the contrary, that the Jews had rule over them that hated them;)
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the divine reversal of the Jews’ fate, showing God’s protection over His people.

keyVerses.text: On the thirteenth day of the month Adar; and on the fourteenth day of the same rested they, and made it a day of feasting and gladness.
keyVerses.significance: It establishes the pattern of rest and celebration that commemorates God’s deliverance.

keyVerses.text: Wherefore they called these days Purim after the name of Pur. Therefore for all the words of this letter, and of that which they had seen concerning this matter, and which had come unto them,
keyVerses.significance: This verse explains the origin of the feast of Purim, a lasting memorial of God’s salvation.

keyVerses.text: And that these days should be remembered and kept throughout every generation, every family, every province, and every city; and that these days of Purim should not fail from among the Jews, nor the memorial of them perish from their seed.
keyVerses.significance: It underscores the importance of faithful remembrance and teaching of God’s deliverance across generations.
